facts.text: Civil Appeal No.426 of 1957 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1955, of the Orissa High Court in Special Jurisdiction Case No. 179 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.426 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1955, of the Orissa High Court at Cuttack in Special Jurisdiction Case No. 179 of 1951.

facts.text: The respondent is the proprietor of the impartible zamin of Jaipur in Koraput District.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the proprietor of the impartible zamin of Jaipur in Koraput District. The estate is of the area of 12,000 sq. miles of which 1540 sq. miles are reserve forest and 100 sq. miles, protected forest.

facts.text: The estate is of the area of 12,000 sq. miles of which 1540 sq. miles are reserve forest and 100 sq. miles protected forest.

anchor.surface_text: The estate is of the area of 12,000 sq. miles of which 1540 sq. miles are reserve forest and 100 sq. miles, protected forest. The respondent derives income from the forests by the sale of timber such as teak, salwood, lac, myrabolam, tamarind, cashewnuts and firewood.

facts.text: Respondent derives income from forests by sale of timber such as teak, salwood, lac, myrabolam, tamarind, cashewnuts and firewood.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent derives income from the forests by the sale of timber such as teak, salwood, lac, myrabolam, tamarind, cashewnuts and firewood. There is numberdispute either as to the receipt of such income or as to its quantum.

facts.text: There is no dispute as to the receipt of income from forests or its quantum; all appears in account books.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute either as to the receipt of such income or as to its quantum. All tat appears in the account books of the respondent. The point in companytroversy is as to whether this income is chargeable to tax.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer by order dated January 31, 1943 held forests not proved planted by respondent, trees spontaneous growth, income not exempt under s.4(3)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: By his 31, 1943, the Income-tax order dated January Officer held that the forests in question had number been proved to have been planted by the respondent, that the trees were of spontaneous growth, and that the income therefrom was number within the exemption under s. 4 3  viii  and this order was companyfirmed on appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Order of ITO dated January 31, 1943 confirmed on appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: ...and this order was companyfirmed on appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The respondent took the matter in further appeal to the Appellate Tribunal,...

facts.text: Respondent contended before Tribunal that ITO failed to consider letter of Dewan dated June 3, 1942 detailing operations in rearing and maintenance of forests.

anchor.surface_text: ...and there put forward the companytention that the Incometax Officer had failed to take into account a letter of the Dewan dated June 3, 1942, which gave a detailed account of the operations carried on by the estate in the rearing and maintenance of forests...

facts.text: Tribunal by order dated April 9, 1946 accepted respondent's contention and directed fresh enquiry into facts in Dewan's letter.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated April 9, 1946, the Tribunal accepted this companytention, and directed a fresh enquiry into the facts mentioned in the said letter.

facts.text: ITO after fresh enquiry found no materials proving plantation, no plantation books or working plans produced, held forests grown naturally, income assessable.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order, the Income-tax Officer again enquired into the matter. He observed that though he gave ample opportunities to the respondent to prove that there was plantation of trees by the estate, numbermaterials were placed in proof of that fact and that neither -plantation books number any working plans for timber plantation had been produced.

facts.text: Tribunal held that forests yielding income could not be virgin forests due to Podu cultivation by hill tribes denuding them periodically.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention urged by the respondent at the hearing was that the facts showed that the forests which had yielded income during the year, of account companyld number have been the virgin forests which had originally grown spontaneously on the hills, because they had been periodically denuded by the hill tribes in the process of Podu cultivation carried on by them.

facts.text: Podu cultivation consists in felling jungle, burning trees, sowing dry grain in ashes without tilling for two years, then abandoning.

anchor.surface_text: What this Podu cultivation means is thus stated in the District Gazetteer, Vishakapatnam, 1907 This companysists in felling a piece of jungle, burning the felled trees and undergrowth, sowing dry grain broadcast in the ashes  without any kind of tilling  for two years in succession, and then abandoning the plot for another elsewhere.

facts.text: Tribunal found evidence of actual cultivation and plantation by zamin authorities meagre, no expenses prior to 1904, amount in 1904 negligible, trees sold not those planted then.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this companytention, the Tribunal observed that though there had been extensive destruction of forests in the process of Podu cultivation, nevertheless, companysiderable areas of virgin forests still survived, that the evidence of actual cultivation and plantation by the zamin authorities was meagre and unsubstantial, that numberexpenses were shown to have been incurred on this account prior to 1904,...

facts.text: Tribunal order covered assessments for five years from 1942-43 to 1946-47, facts same for all years.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned that this order companyered the assessments for five years from 1942-43 to 1946-47, the facts relating to the character of the income being the same for all the years.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: Whether on the facts and circumstances the income derived from forest is taxable under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the respondent, the Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court Whether on the facts and in the circumstances the income derived from forest in this case is taxable under the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Orissa High Court (Panigrahi CJ and Misra J) answered reference in negative (income not taxable).

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Panigrahi, C. J., and Misra, J., who answered it in the negative.

facts.text: High Court found forests in Koraput under Podu cultivation for long period, practically disappeared by 1870, regrown and destroyed by 1901, no virgin forest left.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges then observed that the forests in the Koraput area had been under Podu cultivation for a long period, and that as the result of that cultivation they had practically disappeared even by the year 1870, that the trees had subsequently grown into forests and they had also been destroyed by about the year 1901, and that therefore there companyld number have been any virgin forest left surviving.

facts.text: High Court listed respondent's forest activities: preservation, fostering growth, cultivation by felling/burning, planned exploitation, systematic cutting, planting new trees, watering/pruning etc.

anchor.surface_text: Then they referred to the fact that the respondent had been maintaining a large establishment for the preservation of the forests, and that there had been organised activities  1  in fostering the growth of the trees and preserving them from destruction by man and cattle  2  in cultivation of the soil by felling and burning trees from time to time  3  in planned exploitation of trees by marking out the areas into blocks  4  in systematic cutting down of trees of particular girth and at particular heights  5  in planting new trees where patches occur and  6  in watering, pruning, dibbling and digging operations carried on from time to time .

facts.text: High Court held income agricultural due to cultivation and human skill, most trees sprouts from burnt stumps, no virgin forest, onus on department to prove taxable.

anchor.surface_text: All these and similar operations which have been undertaken by the assessee through his huge forest establishment, show that there has been both cultivation of the soil as well as application of human skill and labour, both upon the land and on the trees themselves. It cannot be assumed therefore that all the trees are of spontaneous growth.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under s.66A(2) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges, however, granted a certificate to the appellant under s. 66 A  2  of the Act, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds burden on claimant of exemption (respondent) to establish it, not on department.

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, we should dissent from the view expressed by the learned Judges that the burden is on the Department to prove that the income sought to be taxed is number agricultural income. The law is well settled that it is for a person who claims exemption to establish it,...

facts.text: Tribunal found no plantations by estate authorities worth the name, trees of spontaneous growth.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Tribunal has clearly found that there were numberplantations of trees by the estate authorities worth the name, and that the trees, the income from which is the subject matter of the assessments, must have been of sponta- neous growth.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Tribunal's finding of spontaneous growth is binding in reference under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: That is a finding of fact which is binding on the Court in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Act.

facts.text: High Court erred in rejecting Tribunal finding based on Podu cultivation significance.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges declined to accept this finding, because they companysidered that the Tribunal had number appreciated the true significance of Podu cultivation. That, in our opinion, is a misdirection.

facts.text: No evidence that estate planted trees after Podu denudation; new growth from stumps spontaneous.

anchor.surface_text: Now, there is numberevidence that as and when the jungle had disappeared under Podu cultivation, the estate intervened and planted trees on the areas thus denuded. On the other hand, the learned Judges themselves found that after the destruction of the original forests in the process of Podu cultivation, there was a fresh growth of forests from the stumps of the trees which had been burnt.

The following are the figures relating to the forest receipts and expenses for the years with which the present assessments are companycerned Years Receipts Expenses 1942-43 Rs. 438,894 Rs. 174,437 1943-44 Rs. 407,447 Rs. 209,895 1944-45 Rs. 552,122 Rs. 228,830 1945-46 Rs. 372,971 Rs. 247,216 1946-47 Rs. 689,366 Rs. 460,369

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court order, answers reference in affirmative (income taxable).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: All these and similar operations which have been undertaken by the assessee through his huge forest establishment, show that there has been both cultivation of the soil as well as application of human skill and labour, both upon the land and on the trees themselves. It cannot be assumed therefore that all the trees are of spontaneous growth. The indications, on the other hand, appear to be that most of them are sprouts springing from burnt stumps... Apart from that it will be noticed that what distinguishes the present case from all the reported decisions is that practically the whole of the forest area has been subjected to process of Podu cultivation spreading over several decades so that it is impossible to say that there is any virgin forest left.

arguments.claim: Facts show trees planted by estate: old forests gone by Podu; planting from 1904 per accounts; infer prior plantations; hill operations expensive; no need prove tree by tree

anchor.surface_text: It is contended by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the respondent that on the facts established in the evidence, the proper conclusion to come to is that the trees sold by the respondent had been planted by the estate authorities, and that the decision of the High Court that the income thus realised is within the exemption under s. 4 3  viii could be supported even on the view of law taken in The Commissioner of Income-tax... The argument was that there was unimpeachable evidence that the old forests had disappeared under Podu cultivation, that the estate had been regularly engaged in planting trees at least from the year 1904 as is shown by the accounts of the zamin,...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the forest income may be taken to have been derived therefrom. And this too, it must be remarked, is only a presumption of fact, the strength of wh

arguments.court_reasoning: Matter of fact appreciation; Tribunal finding final and binding

arguments.claim: High expenses vs receipts infer substantial income from planted trees; per Benoy Kumar observation

court_response_anchor.surface_text: uld be proper to companyclude that the forests were in their entirety the result of plantation. It would be ail erroneous approach, it was argued, to

arguments.court_reasoning: Benoy Kumar context had plantations over 150 yrs; here Tribunal found none; presumption depends on facts

holdings.text: The burden of proof is on the person who claims exemption from tax under the Income-tax Act to establish it, not on the Department.

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, we should dissent from the view expressed by the learned Judges that the burden is on the Department to prove that the income sought to be taxed is number agricultural income. The law is well settled that it is for a person who claims exemption to establish it, and there is numberreason why it should be otherwise when the exemption claimed is under the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled law supported by precedents like Venkataswamy Naidu; High Court erred in placing burden on Department.

holdings.text: Observations in Australian Mutual Provident Society on paramountcy of exemptions relate to construction, not burden of proof.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges were of the opinion that their companyclusion followed on the principle of the law of Income-tax that where an exemption is companyferred by a statute, the State must number get the tax either directly or indirectly , and support for this view was sought in the following observations of Lord Somervell

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent as rule of construction, not affecting onus of proof.

holdings.text: In claims under s.4(3)(viii), assessee must prove income is agricultural; confirmed by Venkataswamy Naidu.

anchor.surface_text: There is ample authority for the view that the principle that a person who claims the benefit of an exemption has to establish it, applies when the exemption claimed is under the provisions of the Income-tax Act... In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Venkataswamy Naidu , this Court held... that it was for the assessee to prove that the income sought to be taxed was agricultural income exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  viii .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct precedent from this Court reversing Madras HC.

holdings.text: Tribunal's finding that there were no plantations of trees by estate authorities worth the name and trees were of spontaneous growth is a finding of fact binding on High Court in reference under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Tribunal has clearly found that there were numberplantations of trees by the estate authorities worth the name, and that the trees, the income from which is the subject matter of the assessments, must have been of sponta- neous growth. That is a finding of fact which is binding on the Court in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision on references; binding nature of Tribunal fact findings.

holdings.text: High Court committed misdirection by rejecting Tribunal's finding for not appreciating significance of Podu cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges declined to accept this finding, because they companysidered that the Tribunal had number appreciated the true significance of Podu cultivation. That, in our opinion, is a misdirection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Podu evidence irrelevant to whether estate planted trees.

holdings.text: No evidence that estate planted trees after Podu denudation; fresh growth from burnt stumps is spontaneous.

anchor.surface_text: Now, there is numberevidence that as and when the jungle had disappeared under Podu cultivation, the estate intervened and planted trees on the areas thus denuded. On the other hand, the learned Judges themselves found that after the destruction of the original forests in the process of Podu cultivation, there was a fresh growth of forests from the stumps of the trees which had been burnt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application to facts; accepts HC's own finding but characterizes as spontaneous.

holdings.text: Agricultural income under s.2(1)(b) requires basic operations like tilling, sowing, planting; subsequent operations like pruning, watering are agricultural only as continuation thereof; spontaneous growth products not agricultural.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, the question what is agricultural income within s. 2 1  of the Act is the subject of a recent decision of this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy  1 . There, it was held that before an income companyld be held to be agricultural income,... It is agreed on all hands that products which grow wild on the land or are of spontaneous growth number involving any human labour or skill upon the land are number products of agriculture

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding precedent from this Court in Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy defining agriculture.

holdings.text: High Court's view that large-scale subsequent operations suffice for agriculture under s.2(1)(b) no longer tenable post Benoy Kumar.

anchor.surface_text: In fairness to the learned Judges... the view they took was that such operations when companyducted on a large scale as in the present case would be within s. 2 1  of the Act. ... This view is numberlonger tenable in view of the decision of this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overrules HC based on intervening SC precedent.

holdings.text: Trees grew spontaneously, not planted by estate; income from sale not agricultural exempt under s.4(3)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: the crucial question to be answered is, were those trees planted by the proprietors of the estate, or did they grow spontaneously ? If it is the latter, it would be wholly immaterial that the respondent has maintained a large establishment for the purpose of preserving the forests and assisting in the growth of the trees, because ex hypothes, he performed numberbasic operations for bringing the forests into being.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Benoy Kumar to Tribunal's fact finding.

holdings.text: High forest expenses do not infer substantial income from planted trees absent evidence of plantations.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that from the high proportion of the expenses in relation to the receipts it companyld be inferred that the income from trees planted by the estate formed a substantial portion of the income derived from the forests. ... These observations do number lay down that if companysiderable amounts are expended in the maintenance of forests, then it must be held that the trees were planted by the proprietors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Benoy Kumar context; Tribunal finding prevails.

holdings.text: Income derived from forest is taxable under the Indian Income-tax Act; reference answered in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal allowed based on above holdings.

precedents.citation: Australian Mutual Provident Society Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.case_name: Australian Mutual Provident Society v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule must be construed together with exempting provisions which must be paramount; rule cut down to prevent indirect deprivation of exemption benefit.
precedents.cited_holding: The rule must be construed together with the exempting provisions which, in our opinion, must be regarded as paramount. So far as the rule, if taken in isolation, would have the effect of indirectly depriving the company of any part of the benefit of the exemption, its operation must be cut down, so as to prevent any such result, and to allow the exemption to operate to its full extent.

precedents.citation: Maughan v. Free Church of Scotland

anchor.surface_text: Vide the observations of the Lord President and of Lord Adam in Maughan v. Free Church of Scotland 1 and the observations of Lord Hanworth, M. R., in Keren Kayemeth Le Jisroel Ltd. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2 at p. 36 that the right to exemption under Section 37 must be established by those who seek it.

precedents.case_name: Maughan v. Free Church of Scotland
precedents.cited_proposition: Person claiming exemption must establish it.

precedents.citation: Keren Kayemeth Le Jisroel Ltd. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue

anchor.surface_text: Vide the observations of the Lord President and of Lord Adam in Maughan v. Free Church of Scotland 1 and the observations of Lord Hanworth, M. R., in Keren Kayemeth Le Jisroel Ltd. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2 at p. 36 that the right to exemption under Section 37 must be established by those who seek it. The onus therefore lies upon the Appellants , and of Lord Macmillian at p. 58 that, In my opinion, the Appellants, have failed to bring it within any one of these categories

precedents.case_name: Keren Kayemeth Le Jisroel Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Right to exemption under Section 37 must be established by those who seek it; onus on appellants to show they fall within exempt categories.
precedents.cited_holding: the right to exemption under Section 37 must be established by those who seek it... In my opinion, the Appellants, have failed to bring it within any one of these categories and consequently have failed in what was essential for them to make out, namely, that this Company is a body of persons established for charitable purposes only.

precedents.citation: Amritsar Produce Exchange Ltd. In re
precedents.case_name: Amritsar Produce Exchange Ltd., In re
precedents.cited_proposition: Those who seek exemption under s. 4 of the Act must establish it.

precedents.citation: Sm. Charusila Dassi and others, In re
precedents.case_name: Sm. Charusila Dassi and others, In re
precedents.cited_proposition: Those who seek exemption under s. 4 of the Act must establish it.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Venkataswamy Naidu
precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Venkataswamy Naidu
precedents.cited_proposition: Assessee claiming exemption for agricultural income under s. 4(3)(viii) must prove it; burden not on Income-tax authorities to prove it is not agricultural income.
precedents.cited_holding: the High Court erroneously framed the question in the negative form and placed the burden on the Income-tax Authorities of proving that the income from the sale of milk received by the assessee during the accounting year was not agricultural income. In order to claim an exemption from payment of income-tax in respect of what the assessee considered agricultural income, the assessee had to put before the Income-tax Authorities proper materials which would enable them to come to a conclusion that the income which was sought to be assessed was agricultural income.

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: Agricultural income requires derivation from land by agriculture involving basic operations like tilling, sowing, planting; subsequent operations alone insufficient; spontaneous growth not agricultural.
precedents.cited_holding: before an income could be held to be agricultural income, it must be shown to have been derived from land by agriculture or by one or the other of the operations described in cls. i and ii of s. 2(1)(b) of the Act, that the term agriculture meant, in its ordinary sense, cultivation of the field, that in that sense it would connote such basic operations as tilling of the land, sowing of trees, plantation and the like, and that though subsequent operations such as weeding, pruning, watering, digging the soil around the growth and removing undergrowths could be regarded as agricultural operations when they are taken in conjunction with and as continuation of the basic operations mentioned before, they could not, apart from those operations, be regarded as bearing the character of agricultural operations... products which grow wild on the land or are of spontaneous growth not involving any human labour or skill upon the land are not products of agriculture and the income derived therefrom is not agricultural income.

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: Subsequent operations alone on spontaneous forests do not make income agricultural.

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: View of law on agricultural income from forests.

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: High expenditure on forest maintenance suggests substantial income from planted trees.
precedents.cited_holding: The expenditure shown by the assessee for the maintenance of the forest is about Rs. 17,000 as against a total income of about Rs. 51,000. Having regard to the magnitude of this figure, we think that a substantial portion of the income must have been derived from trees planted by the proprietors themselves.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Venkataswamy Naidu
precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Venkataswamy Naidu
precedents.cited_proposition: Burden of proof on assessee to establish exemption from income tax.

anchor.surface_text: the crucial question to be answered is, were those trees planted by the proprietors of the estate, or did they grow spontaneously ? If it is the latter, it would be wholly immaterial that the respondent has maintained a large establishment for the purpose of preserving the forests and assisting in the growth of the trees, because ex hypothes, he performed numberbasic operations for bringing the forests into being.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.
